The Second Book of the Satires was published in 30 nc, five years ¹ after the First Book, and the changes which the interval had produced in the temper and in the art of Horace are quite evident; his tone is less persona] and more mellow and he has adopted the dialogue form instead of the monologue. In both respects the change is an advance. The earlier satires‚ with all their geniality‚ are touched here and there with sensationalism‚ and even the later work betrays at times a certain uneasiness about his own position and success. But by the year 30 n.c. Horace, now about thirty-five years of age, had won recognition asa writer. He was secure iu the esteem of a circle of friends ς he had accom- modated himself, not indeed without difficulty, but quite sincerely, to the great political changes which he had at first opposed, and he writes like a man at peace with himself and with his world.
